title: Prophetic interview with Helen Bailey months before her murder revealed author's fears over new life with 'Gorgeous Grey Haired Widower'
text:

Grief-stricken Helen Bailey revealed her fears over her new life with fiancé Ian Stewart in a chilling interview months before her murder. 
Speaking about how she dealt with the death of her husband John Sinfield who drowned in the sea in Barbados in 2011, the author confessed how "different" her life was without him. 
Recalling an incident she included in a memoir about the bereavement, Helen said she wanted John to "just come back and rescue her". 
She told Cambridge News : "We'd been out to dinner at someone's house, and we were walking back along the road, and the sky was inky black, and I suddenly realised that I didn't know any of these people a few years ago. 
"I didn't know Ian, I didn't know the people we'd been to dinner with, I'd never heard of Royston. And for this split moment, the grief just…" 
"I thought 'John, just come back and rescue me. Just come back. The big experiment's over now'. And I felt so alone, so isolated, like I'd been picked up and plonked there. And then it was OK." 
Stewart, 56, was found guilty of murdering Helen and dumping her in a cesspit underneath her £1.2m home in a calculated plot to inherit her millions. Helen Bailey met Stewart shortly after the tragic death of her husband John Sinfield (pictured) (Photo: SOUTH BEDS NEWS AGENCY 01582 572) 
He was found guilty of murder, preventing a lawful burial, fraud and three counts of perverting the course of justice following a six-week trial at St Albans Crown Court. 
The killer preyed upon her on a social media group for widows and widowers. 
Within months of John's death, she was being targeted by Stewart after the pair began chatting online. 
The prosecution described Stewart's pursuit of the millionaire as a 'love-bombing' campaign in which he showed her with compliments and affection. 
She quickly became 'besotted' with Stewart and he rapidly worked his way into her £1.2m home - and later her will. (Photo: Alice Boagey) Ms Bailey wrote Stewart into her will three months before her death (Photo: East Anglia News Service) 
Prosecutor Stuart Trimmer said: "This defendant was intimate, that is the phrase we will use, with Helen Bailey one month after they first met face-to-face. 
"It is perfectly plain she was completely overwhelmed by what some people might call 'love-bombing'. 
"She was absolutely besotted with him - the Gorgeous, Grey-Haired Widower. 
"It is a matter of common sense and knowledge that someone shortly bereaved might not have the logical equipment to see she was being deceived. Helen Bailey was murdered and buried along with her pet Daschund Boris (Photo: SWNS - Cambridge +44 (0)11790665) Stewart stood to inherit her £1.2m Hertfordshire home (Photo: Collect Unknown) Police discovered the body during a search after Stewart's arrest (Photo: John McLellan) 
"And the crown say she was being grossly deceived by someone who was preying on her." 
Tragically, Helen wrote in glowing terms about Stewart in her final book about the loss of her husband.
